verses.text: In the beginning was the Word, and the Word was with God, and the Word was God.
verses.comment: This opening echoes Genesis 1:1, identifying Jesus (the Word) as both present with God and fully God Himself. This is a foundational declaration of Jesus’ divinity, forming the basis for understanding the doctrine of the Trinity. The title 'Word' (Greek, 'Logos') carries deep theological meaning, indicating God's self-revelation and communication with humanity.

verses.text: He was with God in the beginning.
verses.comment: Affirms the eternal pre-existence of the Word. The mention of 'beginning' points to Christ’s presence before all creation, a strong assertion of His divinity and role in the Godhead.

verses.text: All things were made through Him, and apart from Him not one thing was made that has been made.
verses.comment: Jesus is presented as the Creator of all things, a direct affirmation of His cosmic authority. Nothing exists outside of His creative power. This highlights the unity of Father and Son in the work of creation.

verses.text: In Him was life, and the life was the light of mankind.
verses.comment: Jesus is described as the source of all life (both physical and spiritual) and the light that reveals God to humanity. The themes of light and life will be prominent throughout John's Gospel, underscoring the necessity of a living relationship with Christ.

verses.text: The light shines in the darkness, and the darkness has not overcome it.
verses.comment: The victory of light over darkness points to Christ’s triumph over evil and death. The language is reminiscent of Genesis 1:3. The perpetual shining of the light affirms the security of those who follow Christ.

verses.text: There was a man sent from God, whose name was John.
verses.comment: John the Baptist’s role as a divinely-sent forerunner is rooted in Old Testament prophecy. His mission is significant for preparing the way for the Messiah.

verses.text: He came as a witness, to testify about the light, so that all might believe through him.
verses.comment: John the Baptist’s testimony points towards Jesus as the true light, testifying for the purpose of awakening faith in others. Witness and testimony are recurring themes in John's Gospel, highlighting the historical testimony to Jesus.

verses.text: He was not the light, but came to bear witness about the light.
verses.comment: John’s subordination to Christ is made clear — he is not the light himself, but his role is to point toward the true light. This emphasizes Jesus’ unique role in salvation history.

verses.text: The true light that gives light to everyone was coming into the world.
verses.comment: Jesus is described as the 'true light,' fulfilling the universal promise of salvation for all nations, not just Israel. The theme of Jesus as the light of the world runs throughout the Gospel.

verses.text: He was in the world, and the world was made through Him, but the world did not know Him.
verses.comment: This verse emphasizes the irony of the Creator being unrecognized by His own creation. Human blindness and rejection contrast with the self-revelation of God in Christ.

verses.text: He came to His own, and His own people did not receive Him.
verses.comment: Jesus’ rejection by Israel fulfills Old Testament prophecy about the suffering servant. This sets the backdrop for the wider mission to the Gentiles.

verses.text: But to all who did receive Him, He gave the right to become children of God, to those who believe in His name,
verses.comment: Faith in Jesus grants a new relationship with God—becoming His children by grace. The language of adoption is significant for communicating salvation as participation in God's family.

verses.text: who were born, not of blood, nor of the will of the flesh, nor of the will of man, but of God.
verses.comment: This birth is spiritual, not a result of human effort or ancestry. Spiritual rebirth and baptismal imagery are suggested, as will be developed further in John chapter 3.

verses.text: And the Word became flesh and made His dwelling among us, and we have seen His glory, the glory of the one and only Son from the Father, full of grace and truth.
verses.comment: This foundational verse declares the Incarnation—the infinite God taking on human nature. 'Dwelt' literally means 'tabernacled,' recalling God’s presence in the tabernacle. The visible glory of God in Jesus affirms His divine Sonship. The mention of 'grace and truth' foreshadows the sacraments as means of encountering Christ.

verses.text: John testified about Him and shouted, 'This was He of whom I said, “He who comes after me ranks ahead of me, because He was before me.”'
verses.comment: Affirms the preexistence and superiority of Jesus over John. John the Baptist recognizes Jesus’ primacy, highlighting that the one who comes later in time is eternally prior.

verses.text: For from His fullness we have all received, grace upon grace.
verses.comment: The superabundance of Divine grace is given through Christ. This fullness continues to be supplied through the means of grace God provides, especially the sacraments.

verses.text: For the law was given through Moses; grace and truth came through Jesus Christ.
verses.comment: The coming of Christ completes and perfects the old covenant. The Gospel brings a new and greater outpouring of God’s grace and truth, exceeding what was given through Moses.

verses.text: No one has ever seen God; the one and only Son, who is in the Father’s bosom, He has made Him known.
verses.comment: Christ is the definitive revelation of God because He comes from the intimate presence of the Father. The unique closeness implies both intimate relationship and shared divine essence.

verses.text: This is the testimony of John, when the Jews sent priests and Levites from Jerusalem to ask him, 'Who are you?'
verses.comment: John’s identity and authority are of special concern to the religious leaders, showing the widespread expectation of the coming Messiah.

verses.text: He confessed, and did not deny, but confessed, 'I am not the Messiah.'
verses.comment: John denies being the Messiah, emphasizing his role as a forerunner. This prevents confusion with the true Anointed One.

verses.text: And they asked him, 'What then? Are you Elijah?' He said, 'I am not.' 'Are you the Prophet?' He answered, 'No.'
verses.comment: Elijah and the Prophet (like Moses) were both expected figures in Jewish eschatology. John declines both titles, preparing for the one who is greater.

verses.text: So they said to him, 'Who are you? We must give an answer to those who sent us. What do you say about yourself?'
verses.comment: The religious authorities seek clarification for John’s ministry and identity. John’s response will clarify the role of prophecy and preparation for Christ.

verses.text: He said, 'I am the voice of one crying out in the wilderness, “Make straight the way of the Lord,” as the prophet Isaiah said.'
verses.comment: John identifies himself with Isaiah’s prophecy, showing that he prepares the way for the Lord—another hint at Jesus' divinity since the 'Lord' refers to God Himself.

verses.text: Now they had been sent from the Pharisees.
verses.comment: The Pharisees question John because of their role as religious guardians. Their leadership will come into frequent conflict with Jesus.

verses.text: They asked him, 'Why then are you baptizing, if you are not the Messiah, nor Elijah, nor the Prophet?'
verses.comment: Jewish leaders saw John's baptism as unusual apart from messianic authority. His answer points beyond himself to the one who is greater.

verses.text: John answered them, 'I baptize with water, but among you stands one you do not know,
verses.comment: John’s baptism prepares for a greater baptism to come. The one John's preparing for is already present among the people, further creating anticipation.

verses.text: He is the one who comes after me, whose sandal strap I am not worthy to untie.'
verses.comment: John declares his humility compared to Jesus. The act of untying sandals was the work of a low servant—John sees himself unworthy of even this before Christ.

verses.text: These things happened in Bethany across the Jordan, where John was baptizing.
verses.comment: This geographical detail roots the Gospel in history, showing that these were real events. Baptism in the Jordan alludes to new beginnings for God's people.

verses.text: The next day he saw Jesus coming toward him and said, 'Look, the Lamb of God, who takes away the sin of the world!'
verses.comment: John identifies Jesus as the sacrificial 'Lamb of God.' The title connects Jesus with the Passover lamb and the suffering servant, emphasizing his role as the perfect sacrifice to atone for the sins of all humanity—both a literal and a spiritual fulfillment.

verses.text: This is He of whom I said, 'After me comes a man who ranks ahead of me, because He was before me.'
verses.comment: A repetition underscoring Jesus’ preexistence and eternal status, grounds for His superiority even over prophets like John.

verses.text: And I myself did not know Him, but so that He might be revealed to Israel, I came baptizing with water.
verses.comment: John’s mission is to prepare the people for Jesus’ public manifestation. His baptism leads the way for a deeper baptism that Jesus would institute.

verses.text: And John testified, 'I saw the Spirit come down from heaven as a dove and rest on Him.'
verses.comment: The descent of the Spirit fulfills Old Testament prophecy about the Messiah. The visible sign confirms Jesus’ divine anointing and inaugurates His public ministry.

verses.text: And I myself did not know Him, but He who sent me to baptize with water said to me, 'He on whom you see the Spirit descend and remain, this is He who baptizes with the Holy Spirit.'
verses.comment: John’s authority comes from God. Jesus, unlike John, baptizes not just with water but with the Holy Spirit, bringing about the fullness of new life.

verses.text: And I have seen and testified that this is the Son of God.
verses.comment: John the Baptist bears witness to Jesus’ divine sonship, a foundational belief that sets Jesus apart from all other teachers.

verses.text: The next day, John was standing there again with two of his disciples.
verses.comment: John's disciples will now be directed toward Jesus. This shows John’s humility and the new direction for God’s people.

verses.text: And he looked at Jesus as He walked by and said, 'Look, the Lamb of God!'
verses.comment: Repetition of the title focuses attention on Jesus’ sacrificial mission. The early disciples are drawn by the testimony of John to the unique person and work of Christ.

verses.text: The two disciples heard him say this, and they followed Jesus.
verses.comment: John’s ministry is to guide people to Jesus, indicating the importance of authoritative teachers who help others discover Christ.

verses.text: Jesus turned and saw them following, and said to them, 'What are you seeking?' They said to Him, 'Rabbi' (which means Teacher), 'where are You staying?'
verses.comment: Rabbi is a mark of respect. The disciples’ desire to remain with Jesus reflects a willingness to become true learners and followers.

verses.text: He said to them, 'Come and you will see.' So they came and saw where He was staying, and they stayed with Him that day. It was about four in the afternoon.
verses.comment: Jesus’ invitation stresses personal encounter and relationship. The detail about the time also hints that the events are remembered firsthand.

verses.text: One of the two who heard John speak and followed Him was Andrew, Simon Peter’s brother.
verses.comment: Andrew’s first act as a disciple is to bring others to Jesus, reflecting the communal and missionary nature of authentic discipleship.

verses.text: He first found his own brother Simon and said to him, 'We have found the Messiah!' (which means Christ).
verses.comment: The earliest disciples confess Jesus as the Messiah. This confession of faith forms the foundation of the Church’s identity.

verses.text: He brought him to Jesus. Jesus looked at him and said, 'You are Simon the son of John. You will be called Cephas' (which means Peter).
verses.comment: Jesus renames Simon as Peter (meaning 'rock'), pointing forward to his pivotal role in the Church. The new name signifies a change in vocation and identity, often tied to leadership.

verses.text: The next day Jesus decided to go to Galilee. He found Philip and said to him, 'Follow me.'
verses.comment: Jesus handpicks His disciples. The call to 'follow me' reflects radical discipleship in response to divine initiative.

verses.text: Now Philip was from Bethsaida, the same city as Andrew and Peter.
verses.comment: The disciples first called were from the same community. This underlines the close, interconnected foundations of the apostolic witness.

verses.text: Philip found Nathanael and told him, 'We have found Him, the one Moses wrote about in the Law, and also the prophets—Jesus of Nazareth, the son of Joseph.'
verses.comment: Jesus fulfills both the Law and the Prophets, indicating continuity with all that God had revealed previously. Identification as 'the son of Joseph' highlights Jesus’ true humanity.

verses.text: Nathanael said to him, 'Can anything good come out of Nazareth?' Philip said to him, 'Come and see.'
verses.comment: Nazareth’s insignificance as a town underscores God’s way of choosing what is humble and hidden to accomplish His greatest work.

verses.text: Jesus saw Nathanael coming toward Him and said of him, 'Behold, truly an Israelite in whom there is no deceit!'
verses.comment: This statement contrasts Nathanael as one who has integrity, recalling Jacob (Israel) and pointing to the new, faithful Israel Jesus gathers.

verses.text: Nathanael said to Him, 'How do you know me?' Jesus answered him, 'Before Philip called you, when you were under the fig tree, I saw you.'
verses.comment: Jesus displays supernatural knowledge, affirming His divine insight. The reference to the fig tree may suggest contemplation or prayer.

verses.text: Nathanael answered Him, 'Rabbi, You are the Son of God! You are the King of Israel!'
verses.comment: Nathanael’s confession combines titles of high Christology. 'Son of God' recognizes Jesus’ unique divine relationship, and 'King of Israel' His messianic kingship.

verses.text: Jesus answered him, 'Because I said to you, “I saw you under the fig tree,” do you believe? You will see greater things than these.'
verses.comment: Jesus promises even greater revelations to those who believe. Faith opens the way to deeper spiritual truths.

verses.text: And He said to him, 'Truly, truly, I say to you, you will see heaven opened, and the angels of God ascending and descending on the Son of Man.'
verses.comment: This allusion to Jacob’s ladder (Genesis 28:12) points to Jesus as the bridge between heaven and earth, fulfilling the vision of the Old Testament patriarchs and prophets. 'Son of Man' is a messianic title with overtones of divinity and authority. The Church will later be emphasized as the place of this connection—where heaven meets earth.
